addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

28 Octo
b
1590
M
r
Bodeley to my L./.

page.lettertext:
fol.176r
May it please yo
r
L. fower daies past, I
receaved yo
r
L. letter of
e 9 of this moneth:
wherein yo
w
require, that the man of
Dunkerk
should be sent unto yo
w
. I doe not doubt, but
yo
w
have sins understood, that
Count Maurice
hath attempted that surprise, and hath failed of
his purpose. Yo
r
L. may conjecture, that his
intention therein was knowen before to
e
Councel
of state
, and might have bin by me advertised
home. But I doe assure yo
r
L. it is an ex-
ploit, w
ch
e Count undertooke upon
e soddaine,
and concealed it altogether from
e Councel of
state. For whiche they dislike his proceding
very muche, and have resolved, to admonishe
him of it publickly. Moreover it may seeme
unto yow, that
e parties heere, by whome
at
ouverture was made unto me, have not dealt
so sincerely, as they should, but imparted their
secret, aswell to
e Count, as to me. But as
I writte to yo
r
L.
e 21 of Sep
t
e Count
had some secret informac
o
n, by some other meanes,
of
e state of
e towne, and of the weaknes
of it there, where he thought to assault it.
And as for those that are heere, by whome
at
mater at first was disclosed unto me, by all
e
tokens that I can see, whiche are also confir-
med by their solemne protestations, being men
of an honest and upright cariage, and so re-
puted where they live, I can not any way con-
ceave any litle suspic
o
n of their double dealing.
fol.176v
Besides it is manifest by
e very course whiche
was held by the Count, in his sailing and mar-
ching, w
t
out respect, at midday, and in sight
of
e Enemie, wherof I am persuaded, yo
w
are fully advertised by those that were present,
that he was holpen in nothing by
e forsaid par-
ties. For they doe bothe condemne him for his
ill conduction, and affirme w
t
all, w
ch
I doe all-
so ghesse by other circumstance, that he had no
intelligence at all of
e entrance by
e water
gate: w
ch
by their declaration was
e principal
place, for
e execution of his purpose: and
might have bin possessed very easely, with
forces out of
England
, w
t
out suspition of the
Enemie.
M
r
Gilpin
, to whome of late I im-
parted this mater, seemed to learne of
S
r
Francis Vere
in
Zeland
, w
ch
he writte from thens,
as he saieth, to yo
r
L. that
e said entrance
by water, was provided for by
e Enemie.
Howbeit I have, as of my self, this day moved
divers questions a farre of to
e Count, about
that place, by circ
u
stance to feele, whether his
intelligence were
e same, as I had receaved,
and w
at
conceat he had of it. But it appea-
reth by his answears, that he knoweth nothing
of it, but very confusely, and not to that ef-
fect, as I had proposed. This
attempt of Count Maurice being frustrat, be-
cause it may be presumed, that
e Enemie
will sounde and fortifie
e weakest places of
the towne, I can not conjecture, that her
Ma
tie
fol.177r
is desirous, that I should send those persons
into England, for whome yo
r
L. hath written.
Nevertheles not to give
e mater over, till I
see it out of hope, nor to leave any thing un-
assaied, w
ch
may w
t
facilitie bee further per-
fourmed, I have heere agreed w
t
e Pensioner
of Dunkerk,
at he shall presently repaire
into Zeland to his felowe
e Eschevin, and
that bothe of them together, shall send some honest
trusty person to Dunkerk (for whome they
may procure some passeport of course from the
Enemie) and give him some instruction to learne
e particular truth of suche pointes, as shalbe
delivered unto him. Chiefly to observe howe
all thinges stand about
e Water gate, and w
at
other alteration is made in
e towne. Upon
e
returne of this messenger, according to
e like-
lihood of
at report, that he shall make, I will
ether stay, or send
e parties themselves unto
yo
w
: who are also willing unto it, if all con-
tinew as it was: and will alwaies adven-
ture their owne persons, in
e greatest place of
danger in perfourmance of
e enterprise. For
lacke of a cipher, I can hardly write of this
mater, to be well understood, but in open termes:
w
ch
I feare to doe
e lesse, because I can not yet
complaine, that any letter of mine hath hitherto
miscaried. I knowe not as yet
when to looke for any answear to o
r
last Pro-
positions. For I can not perceave by any
conjecture, that they had ever other purpose,
fol.177v
or have at this present, then to temporise, and to
attend a good houre, in
e affaires of
Fraunce
:
w
ch
growing to their liking, I am certainly per-
uaded, they will give her Ma
tie
but a careles
and an insolent answear. And in that respect
I should thinke it very needefull (whiche I
speake w
t
submission to yo
r
L. correction)
at
thereafter as
e
King
shall prosper in his actions,
her Ma
ties
garrisons in
e cautionarie townes,
might be carefully renforced. For I see this
people in
all
their dealing are very headdy and
inconstant, and quickly drawen to doe anything
by those
at manege their affaires: of whiche
e most at this present, are nether well incli-
ned to her Ma
ties
causes, and endevo
r
to exclude
her from all her interest among them. There
are some of North
Holland
,
at are unknowen
unto me, but as I am certified by others, men
of good q
a
litie, and wishing well unto her Hig
nes
who have caused me of late, to be secretly adver-
tised,
that for speciall occasions
, w
ch
they will
not disclose, it behooveth her Ma
tie
to looke unto
Flushing
. I have had
e like warning by other
men heere, who signifie unto me, that it hath
bin debated by some principal persons, in their
privat meetinges, w
ch
way they might be able,
w
ch
they make very easie, to thrust
e Englishe
out of Flushing. For mine owne opinion in
particular, I can by no meanes imagine, that
there is any practise as yet, to attempt it actu-
ally: but yet I take suche discourses to be their
fol.178r
preparatives: and if it goe well w
t
e Kinge
in France, whereby
eir feare of
e Enemie may
be more diminished, they were hardly to be
trusted. To provide for
e worst, I thought
it very requisit, to make some intimation to
e
Governo
r
of Flushing
, of
e caveats that I re-
ceaved. the demande of
Coro-
nel Stuart
, w
ch
her Ma
tie
recommendeth by
Yo
r
L. several letters, is solicited heere by one
M
r
John Skeine
, a Scottishe gentleman, whome
e
King
had very lately imploied into
Denmarke
,
and hath charged going home, to deale w
t
the
states in
at cause. The first of yo
r
L. letters
astouching M
r
Stuart, was delivered unto
me 3 daies past, by M
r
Skeine himself, to
whome in respect of my particular endevo
rs
, I will
not faile to give good satisfaction, and yet re-
member w
t
all, w
at
yo
r
L. doth advise in yo
r
next letter after. I have already recommen-
ed
e sute in her Ma
ties
name to
e states, whome
I finde very greatly perplexed, by reason of
e
letters of Mart. Howbeit for ought I can perceave,
they will never yeld to suche a president, as to
pay
e debtes of other Provinces.
There are many marchants newly come hither, bothe
from
Middlebourgh
and
Amsterdame
, whiche ex-
clame against o
r
nation very bitterly, in every
place where they come, for impeaching their trafficke
w
t
spaine
. They have addressed their com-
plaintes to
e
General states
, who, as it seemeth
at this present, are half resolved to send certain
fol.178v
deputies to her Ma
tie
about it.
And thus I
take my humble leave. From
e
Hage
.
Oc
t
28 A
o
1590.Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
